section.description:
Web publishing applications only. Some users of the Application Server have seen messages that say a port is in use. This topic describes the use of built-in tools in Windows XP and Windows 2003 that determine what process is using a specific TCP/IP port. If you are using some other version of windows, you may be able to use a third-party tool, such as fport, which can be downloaded from http://www.foundstone.com/index.htm?subnav=resources/navigation.htm&subcontent=/resources/proddesc/fport.htm.
At a Windows command prompt, run the command netstat -o. This will output a list of ports, along with the PID (process ID) that has that port open. The output looks something like:
section.example:
C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator>netstat -o Active Connections
Proto Local Address Foreign Address State PID TCP WEBAPPSERVER2:80 199.90.113.2:57434 TIME_WAIT 2636 TCP WEBAPPSERVER2:80 199.90.113.2:57589 TIME_WAIT 2636 TCP WEBAPPSERVER2:80 199.90.113.2:57600 TIME_WAIT 2636 TCP WEBAPPSERVER2:80 199.90.113.2:57608 TIME_WAIT 2636 TCP WEBAPPSERVER2:3389 12.110.143.84:6473 ESTABLISHED 964 TCP WEBAPPSERVER2:2325 192.168.0.13:netbios-ssn TIME_WAIT 0
C:\Documents and Settings\Administrator>

section.description: The sample output above indicates that the local port 80 is being used by process ID 2636. To determine which executable is running as a process ID:

step.description: On the resulting screen, make sure "PID (Process Identifier)" is checked and then click OK.

section.description: Now click on the PID heading to sort the entries by PID. The sample screen below shows that process ID 2636 is alpha5.exe, which indicates that the Application Server is using port 80.
